current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend title 49, United States Code, to improve the national freight policy of the United States,
			 and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , is amended by adding at the end the following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Subtitle III of title 49, United States Code

header.#text: National freight policy; measuring the performance of multimodal freight infrastructure

text.#text:
It is the policy of the United States to improve the efficiency, operation, and security of the
			 national freight network by leveraging investments and promoting
			 partnerships that—
promote economic competitiveness and job creation;
improve the safe and efficient mobility of goods; and
protect the public health and the environment.
The objectives of the national freight policy are—

to promote and advance energy conservation and the environmental sustainability of freight
			 movements;

to facilitate and advance the safety and health of the public, including communities adjacent to
			 freight movements;

to provide for systematic and balanced investment to improve the overall performance and
			 reliability of the national freight network system to move freight,
			 including ensuring trade facilitation and transportation system
			 improvements are mutually supportive;

to promote partnerships between Federal, State, and local governments, the private sector, and
			 other transportation stakeholders to leverage investments in freight
			 transportation projects; and

to encourage adoption of operational policies, such as intelligent transportation systems, to
			 improve the efficiency of freight-related transportation movements and
			 infrastructure.
The goals of the national freight policy are—

to reduce transportation infrastructure-related delays of goods and commodities entering into and
			 out of international points of entry on an annual basis;
to reduce by 10 percent the number of freight transportation-related fatalities by 2018;
to reduce national freight transportation-related carbon dioxide levels by 40 percent by 2030;

to reduce freight transportation-related air, water, and noise pollution and impacts on ecosystems
			 and communities on an annual basis; and
to promote the inclusion of ports in freight network planning and project selection.

header.#text: National cooperative freight transportation research program

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall establish and support a national  cooperative freight transportation research
			 program.

shall offer to enter into an agreement with the  Transportation Research Board of the

			 section as the

quote.#tail:
) to support and carry out administrative and management activities relating to   the governance of

management elements

The National Academies may award research contracts and   grants under the program established

header.#text: Open competition and peer review of research   proposals

research conducted under other cooperative transportation   research programs governed by the

or any other Federal, State, or local

text.#text: Research contracts and grants under the  program may allow peer review of the research results.

collaboration with the	 National Transportation Library; and

text.#text: The national research agenda required under

techniques for estimating and quantifying public benefits derived  from freight transportation

the feasibility of consolidating origins and destinations for freight  movement;

methods for incorporating estimates of domestic and international  trade into landside

means of synchronizing infrastructure improvements with freight  transportation demand;
the effect of changing patterns of freight movement on transportation	planning decisions;
the reduction of impacts on urban communities; and

other research areas to identify and address emerging and future  research needs relating to
